title-group.article-title: The tape strip: facilitating radiographic imaging and surgical procedures in the hand

article-meta.aff: The Department of Plastic, Reconstructive and Hand surgery, Diakonessenhuis, Utrecht, The Netherlands.

body.p: We present a simple, safe, cheap and reliable method of holding the fingers in a particular position to obtain a radiographic image or when operating on the hand. Since 2005 we have used a sterile tape strip (OP-tape, Medline, Kleve, Germany) wrapped around the injured finger. The distal end is kept long. This allows surgeons to hold the tape but keep their hands outside the X-ray beam, protecting the surgeon from avoidable radiation exposure (Figure 1). Extension of the adhesive tape proximally to the dorsum of the hand enhances its grip. Separate strips may be applied to adjacent fingers to hold them in any other position to help with imaging or surgery (Figures 1 and 2). If exposure is required for a surgical procedure, the area may be easily exposed by cutting out part of the adhesive strip (Figure 3). Even in a crushed and partially wet finger the remaining strip will retain its adhesiveness if it is wrapped around. This method has clear advantages over the recently presented technique using Steri-Strips™ (Bhat and Mather, 2010).

caption.p: The adhesive tape with its distal end left long above the mini-C-arm. A Mosquito clip lengthens the additional strip of the other fingers.
The uninvolved fingers are secured in flexion allowing fixation of the fractured finger with a Kirschner wire in the preparation of a Suzuki type frame to provide traction.
The tape is cut wherever the skin needs to be exposed for surgery. The extension of the strip to the dorsum of the hand is seen.
